Johns Hopkins faced several challenges in establishing the university, including:

2. Opposition from locals: Some people in Baltimore were skeptical about the need for a university, and some even opposed the idea. Hopkins overcame this by engaging with the community, answering their questions, and addressing their concerns.

4. Location: Hopkins initially purchased a site for the university in a rural area outside of Baltimore, but it was too far away from the city. He eventually acquired a new site closer to the city, which was more accessible to students and faculty.

Overall, Johns Hopkins overcame these challenges through his determination, resourcefulness, and willingness to seek out expertise and advice. His persistence and vision have left an enduring legacy in higher education.
